awd_titl_txt: Ultrasonic Enhancement of Heat and Mass Transfer in Sorption Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
One way to improve the performance of waste-heat activated cooling systems, such as adsorption systems, is by targeted application of ultrasonic energy, which may make possible the use of abundant low-temperature heat sources to provide cooling.  This project explores how ultrasonic energy, combined with low-temperature heat sources, can realize higher-efficiency adsorption cooling by increasing the rate at which refrigerant vapor is released from the surface of a solid adsorbent.  This in effect creates a thermal compressor that replaces the conventional electric-powered compressor.  At this point, however, the mechanisms by which ultrasound interacts with adsorbed liquid refrigerant are not clear, and these are examined through both experiments and theoretical modeling.  This project also involves significant educational and outreach activities.  To date there has been no central, online, open-source resource for thermally activated heat pump technologies.  In addition to assembling and making available open-source simulation codes and performance data that make it easier to design improved systems, online educational modules are developed for enhancing the understanding of students and practitioners in this field and thus promote wider development and adoption of environmentally friendly heat pump technologies.

Although prior work clearly indicates the potential to improve desorption by applying ultrasonic energy, in general this prior work focused on system-level effects rather than local detailed measurements that would enable improved fundamental understanding.  For example, how much of the improved desorption is due to localized heating, and how much is due to other effects such as mechanical compression/decompression, acoustic softening, etc.?  Our work, rather than emphasizing such system-level performance, instead focuses on detailed, localized measurements and analysis to improve fundamental understanding of these coupled heat and mass transport processes that are crucial not only for adsorption cooling, but also for desiccant drying, food drying, etc.  We also explore a much wider range of adsorbents/refrigerants, in addition to the silica gel/water system studied earlier.  Interestingly, the application of ultrasound may enable new adsorbent materials to be utilized, such as superabsorbent polymers (commonly used in disposable diapers) that can absorb up to 2000 times their own weight in water. Without ultrasound, the use of polymers is limited or even prohibited because of the high temperatures needed for regeneration.  By examining alternative materials like superabsorbent polymers we are able to greatly expand the variety of adsorbent/refrigerant pairs that can be considered for application in adsorption cooling.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Desiccants, which remove moisture from air, are one type of adsorbent material.  Desiccants and other adsorbents work by providing a large surface area for target gas molecules, such as water vapor, to which to adhere in a process called adsorption.  In order to reuse desiccants and other adsorbents it is necessary that they be regenerated, which means that the adsorbed molecules must be removed from the surface.  For example, for desiccants this is often done by heating them such that the adsorbed water molecules are driven from the surface, or desorbed.  But, heating or other regeneration processes require energy, which often is supplied through fossil fuel combustion, and thus not only cost money but can also lead to greenhouse gas emissions.  It is therefore desired to develop regeneration, or desorption, processes that are less expensive and consume less energy.  One approach that was evaluated in this project is the application of ultrasound in addition to heat.  Ultrasound is a type of sound (i.e., vibrations) with frequencies greater than about 20 kHz which is the upper limit for human hearing. It was postulated that such vibrations, or oscillating pressure waves, may lead to enhanced heat and mass transfer that, in turn, would lead to more efficient desorption. The intellectual merit of this project was, first of all, to determine if ultrasound does lead to more efficient desorption (it does), and to determine the fundamental mechanisms about why it does so.  Accordingly, we developed an experimental system in which various combinations of ultrasonic power and frequency were applied to desiccants initially saturated with water, in combination with controlled heating.  The results, for common desiccants including silica gel, activated alumina, and zeolite, showed that the total input power required for regeneration can be reduced by as much as 25% compared to the conventional heat-only approach.  Furthermore, in some cases the required heating temperature was also reduced.  This is especially important for the broader impacts of the project, in that lower heating temperatures mean that solar thermal energy and waste heat become attractive heat sources for adsorbent regeneration.  In other words, it may become possible to use such alternative heat sources rather than fossil fuel combustion, thereby making regeneration both less expensive and resulting in fewer (or no) greenhouse gas emissions. These results may well find applications in industrial gas drying, building air dehumidification, or other adsorption systems where removal of a gas in the environment is desired.


Last Modified: 12/08/2021
Modified by: Patrick E Phelan
